none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from R. H. Whitlock, December 28, 1884
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from R. H. Whitlock, December 28, 1884
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 18 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
JAS. M. CARLISLE, PRES'T,
Whitesboro.
MISS NANNIE C. BREEDING,
V. PRES'T, Houston.
ROB'T F. SMITH, SEC'Y,
College Station.
MISS JOSIE L. WOOD,
Assistant Secretary, Brenham.

TEACHERS'
New Orleans Excursion
ASSOCIATION.

Executive Committee.
J. M. CARLISLE,
Whitesboro.
R. F. SMITH,
College Station.
A. H. WILKINS,
Houston.

New-Orleans 12/28 1884.

Dear Mc Innis,
I have been so
busy that the time has fairly
fulfilled the old adage and actually
"fuges". We have been going round
the city for a few days. The Expo
sition is way behind and I think
it will be at least a month
before things are ready in all
departments. Mother arrived all
right and feels very well apparent
ly, and is enjoying herself to
the "full bent." Our plans at
present are to leave here Friday Jan
2nd, and expect to get to College Sta
tion the next day at 2.P.M. Will
write you again before that time.
Remember me to all. Mallory not
back from Jackson yet. R.H. Whitlock

**Analysis and Transcription of Handwritten Letter**

Okay, so I've got this handwritten letter in front of me. The first thing I see is the letterhead. It’s got a clear structure, almost like a business card or association information. I need to make sure I transcribe it accurately, so let’s break it down into sections.

The letterhead is split into three columns. The left column lists officers: *JAS. M. CARLISLE*, *MISS NANNIE C. BREEDING*, *ROB'T F. SMITH*, and *MISS JOSIE L. WOOD*, with their titles and locations. The center has a prominent graphic with the words *"TEACHERS' New Orleans Excursion ASSOCIATION."* in a stylized font. The right column lists the *"Executive Committee"* members: *J. M. CARLISLE, R. F. SMITH, and A. H. WILKINS*, also with their locations. I'll make sure to preserve that layout.

Next, the date. It's clearly "New Orleans 12/28 1884." The "12/28" looks like a fraction. Good.

Now the actual letter. It begins with "Dear Mc Innis," followed by the body. I'll transcribe it carefully, line by line, paying attention to any unusual words or phrases. I have to capture everything: "I have been so busy that the time has fairly fulfilled the old adage and actually 'fuges'. We have been going round the city for a few days. The Exposition is way behind and I think it will be at least a month before things are ready in all departments. Mother arrived all right and feels very well apparently, and is enjoying herself to the 'full bent.' Our plans at present are to leave here Friday Jan 2nd, and expect to get to College Station the next day at 2.P.M. Will write you again before that time. Remember me to all. Mallory not back from Jackson yet."

I see a few potential areas for careful transcription. The word *"fuges"* looks a little unusual; a quick check confirms it. Also, the phrase *"least a month"* is underlined (I have to maintain emphasis). There are a few hyphenated words at the line breaks: "Expo-sition", "apparent-ly", and "College Sta-tion".

Finally, the signature. It looks like *"R. H. Whitlock"* written at the bottom.

Now, I'll put it all together. I'll use the permitted HTML tags to format this properly. I will preserve the layout as best as I can.
